name: Road coloring conjecture
rephrased: Is there a finite sequence of labels (colors) that can be used to reach a specific node from any starting point in a finite, strongly connected directed graph where each vertex has equal in-degree and out-degree?
implication_form: If the graph is Eulerian (each vertex has equal in-degree and out-degree) and strongly connected, then there exists a finite sequence of labels (a synchronizing word) that, regardless of the starting node, leads to a specific target node.
explained: The Road Coloring Conjecture states that any strongly connected, aperiodic directed graph with a finite number of vertices possesses a universal edge-coloring (assigning colors to edges). This coloring has the property that, from any starting vertex, following a specific sequence of instructions (based on the color sequence) leads unambiguously to a designated target vertex, regardless of the initial position.
related_conjectures: Conjectures related to symbolic dynamics and shift spaces
